subject: RE: [junit] Anyone help me to figure out the java.lang.StackOverflowError problem?
msgSnippet: Dear Stefan Schulze,   there is no Hashset in my code. How could you figure out it is the Hashset problem. May be you give the way to discover it and I will
messageBody:
Dear Stefan Schulze,
 
there is no Hashset in my code. How could you figure out it is the Hashset problem. May be you give the way to discover it and I will try to turn it out following your way.
 
Regards
WEI FUGUO

--- On Wed, 8/6/08, Stefan Schulze <algroth@...> wrote:

From: Stefan Schulze <algroth@...>
Subject: RE: [junit] Anyone help me to figure out the java.lang.StackOverflowError problem?
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wednesday, August 6, 2008, 7:34 AM






Hi Fuguo,

some days ago I nearly went crazy with a bug in my software, which only
occured in some JUnit-tests. After spending lots of time it turned out to be
caused by iterating over a HashSet. I wrongly thought the order doesn't
matter I used the HashSet. Additionally I didn't override the
hashCode()-function s. This causes my program to iterate sometimes (usually
when I run as JUnit-test but quite never when I run with a debugger and
breakpoints - I guess it has something to do with the hashcodes depending on
the allocated memory) in another order.
So the assumption that the order of iteration doesn't matter was wrong and
this causes the failure.

Possibly it's somehow similar to your problem...


















[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
